messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text: Already 1million Ugandan Shillings (250 euro's) been send few days ago. 2million extra will be send today. In a few days another 2million will be send to keep up with the works. It takes 1hour to send the money with Worldremit (alternative for Paypal). We gathered funds from 9 Defiants team members. Thanks for those who contributed and make this possible :)

Money arrived safely, And Paulinho was able to buy first Iron sheeting to finish the roof (see images above), which is essential to protect from monsoon rain. We are close to finish the building in 2 weeks. Including cementing / plastering / painting the walls. After that we will look into the elektricity, which is accesible just around the building. (The elektricity comes from the state itself.)

Rooms where Gino and Dave will be staying are facing north-west. Important to keep them cool.

- Paulinho will ask constructors to add elektricity to the budget?
- Ask how thick the walls are?
- Paulinho will send pictures to the diary 
- Bring Gino in contact with copywriter of the website.

- Order flight tickets
- Let Paulinho know when we arrive and when we leave, and share documents with Government. (This is important to gain access to the Nakivale refugee settlement)
- Payment 4million today 
- Payment next week 2million
- Give erc20 address to Gino
- Send funds to erc20 address of Dave

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.author: Paulinho Muzaliwa
messages.text:
Paulinho comments about the work at Unidos:

While donating , you are creating together a safe space for young refugees to learn, exchange ideas and invest in themselves to create their own opportunities and enhance their livelihoods in this settlements.

However, we empower these people through entrepreneurial skills to enable them create projects that bring impact in this refugee settlement and help themselves as well, we are following this empowerment circle,

- Life-ing: this is all about the personal growth for example self-discovery, Non-violence communication etc.
- Mind shifting: here we facilitate how to generate a great idea, start a business etc
- Embodiments: it all about practicing what you learnt and exchanging challenges that you are passing through in your project.

Then at the end we always organize a pitching panel that people come to present their great ideas and project for those who have started so far.

Gravel/tripe:6√ó50000=300000
Ceiling Materials(plywoods) =650000
Workforce=300000
Total=1667000
I remain with 309000 that we can still buy the half of painting materials .

messages.text:
Paulinho comments:
It is with great pleasure that we are letting everyone know that we are almost done with the construction of our new Hall. This will be a place where can learn and share in a comfortable way. 

Our deepest gratitude goes to everyone who has been able to donate, and support us with funds, ideas and suggestions to make this happen. We are thankful too for everything you have done  to enable us reach goals and take other steps that will improve our lives.
Here was our first meeting with our beneficiary from different programs that we are running here

Dave comments:

Thank you Paulinho for the continuous updates and happy faces. I am sorry I was not able to get back to this sooner. It is close to unbelievable that we are able and allowed to make an impact in this way. I will be sending over the next check today so we can continue to build water harvesting and make progress on the tool acquisitions.

Paulinho explained that such water carriers are very expensive for local farmers. 
End of January we plan to organise the first course, to train farmers in ecological farming

messages.author: Gino | Never sends you PM first
messages.text:
Today we had a meeting with Henry and Vicky in Kampala.

Henry is Lecturer at Kampala University. Teaching Environment and Climate Change studies, and part of a Research and Community outreach program which focuses on food security, energy efficiency, Soil-Water Conservation, livelihood improvement and Entrepreneurship. Hes current project is a reforestation program.

Vicky is founder and Director of Green Hope Farmer‚Äôs Pride, a spin off from the global NGO Farmer‚Äôs Pride International. Her current focus is to establish a organic farming education centre to educate women from more vulnerable backgrounds, such as victims from HIV and teenage motherhood.

We discussed the vulnerabilities and challenges of local farmers and refugees. And some of the pre cautions we should take care off. 

Henry has invited us to a organic farm this Wednesday. Which we gonna visit before we go to Nakivale.

Tomorrow we will be going to the prime minister‚Äôs office for a permission in Nakivale. So far its been a bureaucratic turmoil. Vicky‚Äôs husband is a lawyer, so in case we face more struggles we call her husband‚Äôs support. Fingers crossed. ü§û

messages.text:
KCCA is a educational farm center, funded by the Ugandan government and supported by the United Nations. They focus mainly on training citizens in cultivation of food in small spaces, within urban settings. 

Gino visited this location to understand which solutions can be used to train the farmers from the refugee settlement. Not only urban settings, but also places were people have minimal access to lands are ideal for applying some of these cultivation methods. 

One of the main techniques used is growing vertically (See the stacked pots). They also specialise in hydro culture, which is an ideal farming method to conserve water in arid climates. 


Special Thanks to Henry who organised this.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.author: Gino | Never sends you PM first
messages.text:
Talking with several people active in and around this field. It is clear that what we are supporting and funding is unique in Uganda. As till this day no successful Sustainable farming project was setup. 

While KCCA teaches people in these techniques, Henry told us it is hard to scale, as people have lack of determination. 

If we can built out a successful pilot in a refugee settlement we have a case study that could be scaled to other refugee camps. 

Thanks again for all the support üôè

messages.text:
And still there are people who cant eat more than once per day.

To give you some details. The monthly ration food per person at the start of Covid food crisis was:

12kg mais
2kg beans
1l cooking oil

Then the food rations stopped and they shifted to giving 15k shillings or 5$ per month

Resulting in malnutrition, teenage prostitution and child labour to sum one of the most critical side effects.

messages.text:
The same day the representatives of the Commander of Nakivale, and a executive of the agriculture department came for a visit.

They were aware the program was struggling to get off the ground prior our funding. And were happily surprised things had improved so much.

They said they could help with extra land, a possibility to drill a hole for water, and access to seeds.

messages.text:
Map of Unidos land. 

Zone 1 means: anything that need daily watering and or weeding out. Usually this is called the kitchen or backyard garden

Zone 2 means: anything that is sustained for larger production and requires 3-4 times care per week (depending on season)

Grey water means: waste water from dishwashing or bathing.

In the design of water conservation grey water can still serve as a source for watering multi year brushes, such as raspberries.

In the right corner you can see the compass and where North is pointed.

Knowing the wind directions can tell us where we can grow half shadow needing plants such as basil.

text: For those curious, Unidos had a variety of activities that empower the youth of Nakivale. Next to yoga, they also organised breathwork therapy sessions.

text.text: "Launching in a pandemic‚Äã. Eight months into the COVID-19 pandemic we started a conversation with Unidos Social Innovation Center in Nakivale Refugee settlement, in Uganda, Africa to introduce breathwork. A project which aims to empower refugee youth in their growth and healing. In March 2021 we launched the first beta program which was experienced by the team of Unidos and youth fellows from all over the refugee camp."

text.text: "Women don‚Äôt need to find a voice, they have a voice, and they need to feel empowered to use it, and people need to be encouraged to listen.‚Äù

text:
- Meghan Markle. 

After planting 1,000 trees in the Nakivale refugee settlement, it was also a good time for this unstoppable group of women to get together and discuss how women can become more involved. 

Their discussion involved how to play more important roles in business and how to become a crucial component of change in health, food security, clean water, etc. This was not only for their respective communities but also how to foster their collaboration for quickly achieving common goals. 

Paulhino (Founder Unidos):

text.text: "We are grateful to Defiants for the support to make all this happen and for joining us on this year's International Women's Day."

text.text: 10 people graduated during the Permaculture Design Certificate course
teaching local farmers in more efficient ways to cultivate food. Congratulations!

text:
ü•≥

As some of you recall, we embarked on this journey with Unidos to train local farmers, because the Covid pandemic closed down supply chains threatening the 100k people living in Nakivale with famine. This was an alarming signal of how vulnerable people in the refugee settlement are. Therefore Unidos switched its focus to train these farmers. 

Paulinho (Founder Unidos) Said:

text.text: "It was great to finish the course; we have also distributed some of the tools we bought, such as watering cans and hoes."

text:
He apologized for the photos being of poor quality due to the weather.

Thank you to all donators for your support! üôåüî•üå±

messages.author: Gino | Never sends you PM first
text:
Long time since we updated.

Unidos is about to scale with a Greenhouse and bought the land next to their original plot. See zone2

To support the next step, Paul and 3 permaculture teachers went to Kampala capital to learn how to make a greenhouse productive. Among other practical systems that will support their sustainable agriculture plan.

Please check out below, Paul sharing a report.

Then have a tour of what they are doing, for example, the aquaponics system, green house maintenance, a short introduction of the vermicompost, how to prepare seedlings, and food tower that we started practicing our own there

messages.author: Gino | Never sends you PM first
messages.text:
Hey guys,
We have done yesterday, our training and return to the settlement today,
It has been a great experience and worth practicing, we bought some materials with us that we will use to replicate what we learned at KCCA, for example, the food towns, and we can't wait to start with our greenhouse prototype; we are so grateful for Defiants support to enrich our capacity building that will help us to accelerate and innovate great things to reach our goals.

messages.text:
Its amazing to witness how permaculture is really becoming a lifestyle in Nakivale, and help to give people hands on tools to tackle an otherwise intimidating monster. 

It is not an easy time for refugees, the food prices in the world tripled, just after a pandemic had shut down all supply lines.

People are endangered with famine. How amazing the work that Unidos is doing, has a strong impact on building the identity of the refugee. 

Bringing new technology and education to the brave down in Nakivale, Thank you Unidos and your community üôè

messages.text:
Paul and his team will soon visit other villages to setup permaculture systems and teach people how to cultivate food in very scarce terrain. 

They will teach efficient methods to decompose green waste for the production of fertilizer; Using compost worms. 

How to protect crops from mold and insects; In a greenhouse, built with recycled bottles.

And how setting up tower gardens to grow in small plots of land.

messages.text:
We are thrilled again to be able to recruit new students at Unidos; with the full support from Defiants, we are teaching two cohorts consecutively, seeing the current need for food and request for our service in different communities here in Nakivale,
One cohort is studying at Unidos Center, and another one is in a village called Kabahinda, located within Nakivale

messages.text:
The education center of Unidos, where people are studying the basics of permaculture; how make compost with worms, how manage water with covering the soil, how to protect crops from pests with making raised beds. All these innovative things people are learning through permaculture.

And super sweet they have added our logo to their uniforms. 

These uniforms help to show Unidos is seriously involved in what they bring to the refugee settlement, it builts credit with the local government, which might give free land at some point to scale the technology of permaculture.

messages.text:
Paul and his team are amazed with how eager the students were, when learning to apply the 3 ethics of permaculture: people care, fair share, and earth care, into their daily life. 

By sharing opportunities and co-creation in a sustainable way to enhance livelihood of each other, refugees feel more empowered building resilient ecosystems in their direct environment.

messages.text:
We are thrilled today to be able to graduate 37 people from Kabahinda village after two weeks of training in sustainable agriculture and provide tool kits ( Hoe and watering can) for all the participants; we are grateful to all Defiants supporters who are making all these impacts that bring change and save all these families out of the hunger crisis in Nakivale refugee settlement,
I can't wait to share with their gratitude towards how your donation makes a difference in their lives

On this International Refugee Day, we here at UNIDOS in the Nakivale Refugee Camp, are celebrating our success & impact on fellow refugees. We take great pride in announcing that we have successfully trained more than 750 people here, using regenerative life-sustaining agriculture techniques.

The Refugees here and around the world, are faced with difficult challenges and uncertainty. As would be anyone uprooted from their homes, community, and culture. And we know firsthand that adaptation to refugee life is an important key to sustainable human life and survival.  

Through our day-to-day lives, our community stands together in unity, determined to make our lives and our children's lives better.  The complex life situation that we are now passing through inspires us to co-create and innovate our own opportunities within the refugee settlements. And teaches and strengthens us to face the challenges for humanity ahead. And this challenge convinces us that we will succeed in the challenges life presents to us ahead.

This important success has been accomplished by providing the training, tools, and seeds for refugees here to grow their own food. And by promoting food security, enhancing livelihoods, and deep adaptation to life through building resiliency & sustainability in our refugee community.
We are deeply grateful for the tremendous support that Defiants is providing to UNIDOS and enabling us to reach our goals and save millions of refugees here out of hunger

messages.text:
What a great start to the week!  

We have been able to graduate 30 permaculture scholars and donate a toolkit to them consisting of a hoe, watering can, and seeds box. 

It means a lot for us to see this achievement. We can't wait to testify on the impact, and how these people have contributed to our vision. The vision of transforming Nakivale into a completely regenerative refugee community.

messages.text:
The Nakivale Refugee Settlement is home to 150,000 refugees from the Congo, Burundi, Somalia, Ethiopia, South Soudan, and Eritrea. According to statistics from the UNHCR, 76% of this population are Women and Children.

Research shows that if women farmers had the same access to productive resources as men, they could increase yields by 20 to 30 percent and total agricultural output by 2.5 to 4 percent. And this would  lift 100 to 150 million people out of hunger.

Empowering women and girls with diverse skill development and access  to adequate tools is crucial to food security and boosting their productivity and incomes.

"When a woman is empowered, it is the family which is in turn empowered." 

(Factors contributing Women Empowerment, by Dr. S. Franklin John, Nilufar Sathiq

text:
What is so enhancing about worm poop?

Vermicomposting is a real growthhack for communities that can only depend on farming for their livelihood but also their health.

Good worm castings can contain almost all 16 essential elements for plant health. As well as plant growth hormones like gibberellins, a wide range of vitamins including B12, and nitrogen fixing microbes. Worm castings are so beneficial that compared to regular compost they can contain 1000 times more bacterial life.

As worm castings contain more nutrients and bacteria than any other fertilizer. It also includes minerals such as nitrates, phosphorus, magnesium, potassium, calcium, manganese, copper, zinc, cobalt, borax, iron, carbon and nitrogen. Worm castings also contain enzymes and humus. The finished product is neutral pH of 7.0.

It enhances plant growth by allowing the development of new shoots and leaves, resulting in increased productivity.

messages.text:
Women as entrepreneurs can lead to tremendous positive social change that can help make women financially empowered and independent. This in turn can increase levels of confidence and happiness in women. And the resulting satisfaction of achievement and self-sufficiency can boost their self-esteem and overall well-being. 

We realized that teaching entrepreneurship for women is a vital tool to empower women in refugee settlements.  And it promotes gender equality, improves the overall status of women in the family, society, and the nation. 

Unidos is organizing this event with these incredible women entrepreneurs and changemakers. And it is a great opportunity for them to share and inspire other women in the Nakivale refugee settlement through their success stories of turning problems into opportunities. 

We can't wait to see you all attend and hear from these strong women.

text:
It has been a great weekend and was well spent hearing from incredible and unstoppable women how they used their pain, suffering and complex situations to turn all of that into  determination and the creation of new opportunities. And from that they have in turn helped hundreds of other women become self-reliant.
 
We couldn't agree more with them that each of their stories as entrepreneurs can and will motivate, inspire and change many lives in a positive way. And this will become one of the key factors for our community to grow, flourish and prosper.

Every action counts. And you can be part of this success story and share in the joy and hope that these women bring that will inspire more women in the Nakivale refugee Settlement. Please reach out to us at

We welcome your support with open arms, love, peace and gratitude.

Our sincere gratitude to Minak and Tumaini for refugees  who organized and put on such a great event.

messages.text:
The food tower garden is a vertical heap of soil held by a wire mesh on which crops are grown along the wire mesh surface and on top of tower.
It has a column of aggregates in the middle through which watering of crops is done.
Soil, mixing with compost, this can accommodate over 250 plants üçÄ depending on type of vegetables grown with the key benefits of enabling vegetable growing all year round, it can fit in small spaces especially in Urban areas, it is suitable as backyard gardening technology and gives good vegetable harvest for food , nutrition and income

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
What does Regeneration means for us?
Regeneration means to design human systems that co-evolve with ecological systems to generate mutual benefits and greater expression of life and resilience. However, this means for us to shift from the dependency on an organization like the World Food Program and start taking care of the soil by applying more vermicompost, planting more trees to mitigate climate change then start growing our food by following permaculture design and regenerative agriculture technique
We are thrilled to see after following up with our precious participants that we trained have practiced all single designs that we taught to their small space; it is such a great pleasure that we are slowly promoting food security in the Nakivale refugee settlement,
Thanks for all your generosity in supporting our cause and saving hundreds of families from the hunger crisis

messages.text:
Happy start of the week,
We are pleased to see how permaculture is making a difference in different communities that we have been able to facilitate this course,
While we keep making follow-ups of our previous participants, we visited one group who teamed together and were able to contribute money and hired two acres of land where they will be practicing and demonstrating what they learned. So far, they have made a rice nursery üåæthat will be transplanted next week; they want to shift from consumption to business what they will be harvesting from this demonstration land.
We are grateful for everyone who is making this possible and particularly for Defiants üôè

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
At UNIDOS, we are excited to see how productive this year has been so far. Many great things have happened, and among those we have won a community vote for an award organized by the "Social Impact Award".

Through our new project, Regesoil, our goal is to demonstrate and promote methods to enrich the soil with worm casting, which is known as "vermicomposting". This is one of the most powerful ways to regenerate the soil and prevent erosion. 

We are also grateful to everyone who voted for our project. And to the community that ensured us that the solution we came up with responded to the problem. Their voting for this project helped us win a Social Impact Award and is further evidence of the merits of our solutions based projects. 

Thanks to Social Impact Award for organizing this amazing competition. It has enabled us to reach a vast audience and learn so much more from it. 

Stay tuned for what's coming next.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
"Soil is the source of life; your connectedness with it is vital for a strong life," Sadhguru.

We are thrilled to start educating farmers about  composting with worms called vermicomposting, a suitable organic fertilizer that contains most nutrients in plant-available forms such as phosphates, exchangeable calcium, soluble potassium, and other macronutrients. 
The most exciting part is when you add vermicompost to the soil, it enhances soil structure and drainage. Vermicomposting has also increased plant growth and suppresses plant disease and insect pest attacks.

We have had a tour of our demonstration site, which has been an inspiring moment demonstrating the practice to our participants.

As we have finished the introduction and maintenance, we look forward to teaching a financial model to those who would like to develop their site for business purpose

Stay tuned for more updates

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
When we use Permaculture designs to meet our needs, we should do so in a way that supports the ecosystem as a whole. 

However, permaculture is not a specific recipe, nor is it an endpoint. Instead, it is an ongoing process of harmonious adaptation to nature's changing conditions. 

With Permaculture, farmers can create a positive relationship between humans and agriculture, which is needed for adaptation and survival.

 In other words, Permaculture seeks natural methods to create an abundance of successful crops in harmony with nature's natural resources.  

 It is an exciting time to see our participant's designs and how everyone is learning, growing & evolving with this. Stay tuned for more updates.

messages.text:
After 3 weeks together it is an honor for us to have you graduate from our Permaculture Design Course.

This moment is unforgettable and it was a blast having you as our students in this course and group effort.

We taught and learned from you guys and it was an amazing experience. We wish this adventure could be endless

We have a strong conviction that you will make a difference in the community with the skills that you acquired during this short period. 
we will continue to support you wherever we can. And to encourage this co-creation and this important relationship that we have built.

Quite a few events have happened the last weeks. We have bad and good news. 

The bad news is that Paulinho the founder of Unidos did not succeed to arrange Visa to travel to Austria to partake in the finalist pitching contest,

The good news is that we were one of the 15 selected by UNHCR among 1800. Yes you read that right, 1800 participants from 18 countries that applied for funding.

This funding will help Unidos to invest in buying new land, infrastructure, transportation for bringing in green waste, and equipment to monitor parameters such as ph, moist, temperature essential to the health of the worm‚Äôs ecosystem. 

Hope this will be established quite soon, to improve the successrate of the project. 

Stay tuned for more news to come in the next coming weeks. üå±

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
A recent UN (UNHCR) report says that approximately 16,000 new refugees arrived at the Nakivale Refugee Camp in Uganda between March and August 2022. 
This influx has resulted in further shortages of food, which has in turn led to conflicts between refugees and Ugandan farmers, who have accused refugees of stealing food from local farms. 

In October 2021, the monthly stipend for Nakivale refugees was reduced by almost a third from 19,000 Ugandan shillings ($5) to 13,000 shillings ($3.40), says Abdirahman Meygag, the World Food Program (WFP) representative and country director for Uganda.   

At UNIDOS, we and our partners are committed to responding to this challenge in several ways. 
First, by educating refugees about the more efficient and productive regenerative agricultural approach and also by providing adequate tools and seeds. 
Secondly, by inviting people to co-create a resilient community where everyone will be able to grow their own food. 
And third, to grow additional food for general consumption and create businesses to generate income from this that could help respond to other basic needs.  
 
We would be pleased to have you join our cause and help end food scarcity in Nakivale and elsewhere in the world with the tools and methods we have and are developing and will be sharing with the world.  
 
There are different ways to help, including donating to our cause and volunteering with us.
You can contact us in the following way:

messages.text:
Hi everyone,

This is me Paulinho, founder of Unidos, and today I like to share a few words with you as we are wrapping up this year. 

We cannot thank you enough for your generosity! And the commitment to support us in many different ways. Including investing your time and energy to help move us closer to our vision. And for helping us transform the Nakivale Refugee Settlement into a regenerative community, where everyone will become self-sufficient. 

We firmly believe that through developing strong entrepreneurial skills we will be able to co-create and build resiliency. And perhaps most importantly turn the complex and often painful situations that adversely impacted our lives in our home countries into ultimate stories of success. 

You can't imagine how your donations have made such a big difference, and impacted the lives of many refugees in so many important ways. 

We can't wait to work again with everyone next year. 
We wish you a special holiday season.
And thank you for all you have done. 

Unidos teamüôè

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
What a delightful time we have had welcoming new participants to our Permaculture Design Course. This is the first group of students this year and kicks off our 7th class on this subject, and is the first one for 2023. 

During our initial session, we heard participants' expectations and what they dream of achieving after completion of this course. And Unidos will support them in their journey to ensure they are achieving their goals. 

Join us, and together, we can turn their dreams into reality.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
Ensuring the sustainability of refugee settlements means providing for the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. 

To achieve this, Permaculture - a holistic design system for sustainable living - can be a powerful tool. It emphasizes practices like regenerative agriculture, energy-efficient design, and waste reduction, which can all contribute to the long-term sustainability of a settlement.

In addition to permaculture, another important approach is regeneration. 

This involves actively revitalizing ecosystems and communities, which may include initiatives like reforestation, sustainable agriculture, and job training programs to help refugees build skills and find employment. 

By combining both Permaculture and Regeneration, we can create refugee settlements that meet immediate needs while also contributing to the long-term well-being of the environment and society.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
Paulinho was invited today to a meeting organized by the Office of the prime minister and UNHCR, OPM explained how we could work in collaboration with them, and UNHCR talked about the humanitarian aid crisis that they are currently facing, now OPM is expecting refugees' initiatives and projects to fill this gap that UNHCR can't fill at the moment.

They are convinced that this  will make a significant impact as we know better the problem that refugees are going through;and furthermore, we are also part of these people.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
A good environment starts with healthy soil.

In the Nakivale Refugee Settlement, a large part of the land has clay soil, on which farmers are struggling to grow food. 

Today, we learned the value of regenerative agriculture and the benefits of using permaculture methods to improve soil health. Through our vermicomposting method, our participants were excited to understand and visualize the difference between clay soil and healthy soil. 

Regeneration of the soil is the starting point to grow healthy organic food and will also help end food scarcity in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement. 

Let's spread the word and create a regenerative future, not only for Nakivale, but for our planet as well.

See contact information below if you would like to find out how you can help here in Nakivale and elsewhere.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
After learning about the three Ethics of permaculture, which are Earth care, People care, and Fair share, we can use them as starting points for designing and thinking about ways of living. These Ethics motivate us to brainstorm about different ways of taking positive action in everything we do.

However, we have come to realize that the People care ethic is the center of enabling us to build relationships between us refugees, as we come from different communities, cultures, and backgrounds. It is essential to maintain harmony in everything we do, including taking care of ourselves, feeling a sense of belonging to a certain community, maintaining open communication, showing respect, and more.

As refugees, we face many challenges, and it can be easy to feel disconnected and isolated from the wider community. However, by practicing People care, we can create a sense of unity and togetherness that will help us overcome these challenges. By supporting each other, we can build a strong, resilient community that will be able to thrive even in difficult circumstances.

Also, People care is not just about caring for ourselves and our fellow refugees. It is also about extending that care and compassion to the wider community, including our host communities. By building bridges between ourselves and those around us, we can create a more inclusive and supportive environment that benefits everyone.

text: Exciting news! With the ethics of permaculture, we have introduced the 12 principles. We explained the first principle, 'Observe and Interact,' and with it, we encourage learners to develop critical thinking skills for each situation before applying a solution. By observing and understanding the relationships between various elements, we can create solutions with a huge positive impact on the community.

messages.text:
What an amazing day! 

Congratulations to all of our exceptional graduates of the cohort 7! 

These committed students have completed their Permaculture program after three weeks of hard work and dedication. We are so proud of their achievements and can't wait to see how they will apply their knowledge to create healthy, sustainable ecosystems. 

"Here is a successful future full of abundance and harmony!" 

Once again, congratulations.

messages.text:
Coming up with a design for your garden can give you control over it, increase your yields and reduce your environmental footprint. 

With our Permaculture Design course, we not only help you become the best designer for your garden, we also assist you in understanding nature's principles. 

And this will encourage you to shift your perception, thinking, and actions, as you begin creating new ways of thinking, living and working with nature .

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
We want to emphasize that our classes focus not only on theory but also on practice. We encourage participants to turn their sustainable ideas into preventive actions that can bring about change in their lives and expand their community.

After designing their ideas on paper, we help our participants bring them to life by implementing projects. 
Some examples include a sac mount garden and a kitchen garden, and a demonstration of the importance of crop rotation.

It's important to note that these designs are intended for people who don't have much space for farming. Even with limited space, participants can grow enough food for their consumption.

We believe that hands-on learning is essential for creating real change in communities. 

By providing opportunities for our participants to put their ideas into practice, they can see the impact of their actions and feel empowered to create change in their own lives and communities.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Great news from Nakivale refugee camp! 
We had a fantastic conversation today with Olivia and Yvette from Q-point B.V about soil regeneration and the innovative regenerative agriculture techniques we're implementing to grow healthy food while also taking care of the soil.

Q-point B.V is an expert in consultancy projects for agro-food businesses, donors, and public institutions in various agro and food markets. 
We're thrilled to explore potential collaboration opportunities and work together towards sustainable agriculture and a healthier future. 
Stay tuned for more updates on our progress!

messages.text:
As Easter is celebrated around the world, we would like to take a moment to extend our warmest holiday greetings to all, and invite you to join us in exploring the beauty of nature at Unidos. 

Our gardens and natural surroundings serve as a powerful reminder of the countless blessings that Mother Earth can offer us, if we commit to nurturing and preserving her in return. 

Let us take this time to reflect on the importance of sustainability and cherish the gifts that nature provides us.

messages.text:
We're excited to announce that we've harvested our organic fertilizer from our vermicompost site! 

This high-quality fertilizer will be a valuable addition to our gardens, improving soil fertility, aeration, porosity, bulk density, and water retention, especially during dry seasons. 

By using vermicompost, we can enhance our crop yield and look forward to seeing the positive impact it will have on our plants.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
We've had an incredibly busy and rewarding two weeks in the Kiretwa community! As refugees, we were thrilled to have the opportunity to share our knowledge with 65 amazing farmers and teach them about the principles of Permaculture.

During our time there, we introduced the three ethics of Permaculture: Earth Care, People Care, and Fair Share. We also demonstrated various regenerative agriculture designs that could help these farmers take control of their crops while also promoting healthy growth.

To wrap up our course, we conducted a visual soil assessment to help the farmers better understand their soil and determine what approaches they could take to improve its fertility and maintain it in the long term.

We're so grateful for this opportunity to share our skills and knowledge with the Kiretwa community, and we're excited to see how these farmers will put their new knowledge into action to create a more sustainable and resilient future.

text:
Happy Labor Day from the Unidos teamüòä!

Today, we celebrate the incredible milestone that we have achieved as an unstoppable team. We are grateful for the opportunity to make a positive impact on the lives of refugees in the Nakivale refugee settlement.

We would like to extend our sincere gratitude to

.org and all of our amazing partners for their unwavering support of our cause. It is through your generosity that we can continue our efforts toward improving and enhancing the livelihoods of refugees.

We invite you to join us in our mission to create a better future for refugees. Your contribution, no matter how small, can make a significant difference in the lives of those who are in need. Together, we can create a brighter tomorrow for all.

Thank you for your continued support, and we wish you a joyful Labor Day!

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
Happy weekend everyone.

I hope this message finds you well. As we head into the weekend, I wanted to take a moment to draw your attention to the incredible work being done in Nakivale refugee settlement.

The impact of our efforts in Nakivale has been truly remarkable. We are working to create a resilient community where everyone has access to an abundance of food, in a sustainable and regenerative way.

I urge you to take just 5 minutes out of your day to read more about our co-creation process and the progress we have made. Your support and attention can make a significant difference in the lives of these refugees, who have already been through so much.

Thank you, and have a wonderful weekend.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
There is no shortage of definitions for the term "Regeneration". 

However, when it comes to our work with refugees, we firmly believe that regeneration is the key to empowering individuals to become self-reliant and shift away from relying solely on humanitarian aid.

Through our efforts, we are striving to create a resilient community where refugees can grow organic, abundant food while simultaneously regenerating the soil, accessing quality education, and clean water.

As Unidos, we are committed to co-creating this community in a seemingly hopeless environment, such as a refugee camp. We believe that through collaboration and dedication, we can help refugees build a better future for themselves and their families.

Thank you for your support in this important mission.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
üåçüí™ Empowering Refugee Women: Unidos Bridges the Gap in Nakivale Refugee Settlement üí™üåç

Did you know that in the global population of displaced people, women and girls make up a significant portion? In Nakivale refugee settlement, home to over 150,000 refugees, 50% of the population consists of women. Unfortunately, these individuals face immense vulnerability not only due to displacement but also due to the lack of economic opportunities, which hinders their ability to support their families.

But there's hope! Meet Mariam Antoine, the head of women's empowerment at Unidos. She passionately explains how Unidos is bridging the gap and empowering women to reclaim their power and contribute to the well-being of their community.

At Unidos, we understand that empowering women means empowering entire communities. Through our programs and initiatives, we provide the necessary tools and resources for women in Nakivale to gain financial independence and build a better future for themselves and their families.

From teaching regenerative agriculture and permaculture to organizing soap-making classes, we empower women to become self-sufficient and establish their own businesses. By harnessing the power of sustainable practices and natural resources, we not only address immediate needs but also create long-term solutions.

Join us in supporting Mariam and the incredible women of Nakivale. Together, we can break barriers, foster resilience, and build a stronger, more inclusive society for all.

Learn more about Unidos and our impactful work at
. Together, let's empower refugee women and create lasting change. üí´ü§ù

text:
üåæü™≤ Battling Agricultural Pests in Uganda: Teaching Farmers Sustainable Solutions ü™≤üåæ

Pests pose a major threat to agricultural production, hindering efficiency and causing significant losses for farmers. This, in turn, leads to food shortages within the community.

At UNIDOS, we find it crucial to equip farmers with the knowledge and skills to effectively manage pests. By teaching them how to make organic pesticides and improve soil health, we empower them to take control of their farms and ensure sustainable farming practices.

Together, let's combat pests, protect crops, and foster food security in Uganda.

text:
üåøüåç Inspiring Start to the Week: Permaculture Design Course in Juru Village üåçüåø

What an amazing start to the week! We are thrilled to share that we introduced the Permaculture Design Course in Juru village. The first session, focused on the 3 Ethics of Permaculture, was met with enthusiasm and active participation from all the attendees.

The energy and engagement displayed by the participants warmed our hearts and reinforced our belief in the power of knowledge-sharing and community collaboration.

We extend our heartfelt gratitude to the local leaders for their unwavering support and active participation in making this initiative possible. Together, we are creating a sustainable and thriving future for Juru village.

Stay tuned for more updates on our Permaculture Design Course as we continue this incredible journey of learning and transformation!

text:
üåçüå± Celebrating World Environment Day: Taking Steps to Care for Mother Earth üå±üåç
On this special occasion of World Environment Day, we are reminded of the countless ways we can contribute to the well-being of our environment and Mother Earth.

At Unidos, we firmly believe in the power of education to inspire change. One crucial aspect of caring for our planet is nurturing our soil through the application of organic fertilizer derived from our vermicompost site. 
By transforming food waste into vermicompostü™±, we shift human activity from an extractive to a regenerative process.

Healthy soils play a vital role in sequestering carbon, enhancing water absorption during heavy rainfall, and promoting the growth of organic food by enriching nutrient content.
Join us in our mission to foster sustainable practices and create a healthier planet for future generations. Together, let's make a positive impact on the environment and build a greener, more sustainable world.

Happy World Environment Day!

text:
üåøüå± Celebrating our Permaculture Success and a Prestigious AwardüèÜ! üå±üåø

Today, we are filled with joy as we celebrate the incredible work we have done in educating people about Permaculture and regenerating our lands. Witnessing the individuals we have trained grow an abundance of food is truly rewarding.

But the excitement doesn't stop there! We are thrilled to announce that we have received the prestigious Permaculture Magazine Award, organized by the amazing Lush Spring Prize. This recognition further validates our efforts in creating a sustainable and resilient future.

We extend our deepest gratitude to all our partners who have joined and supported us throughout this journey. Your unwavering commitment and support have fueled our progress and brought us closer to our vision.

Together, let's continue to cultivate a thriving and harmonious world through the power of Permaculture.

text:
üå± Strengthening Bonds: Permaculture Unites Refugees and Host Communities ü§ù

Permaculture continues to make a profound impact by fostering meaningful connections between refugees and host communities. We firmly believe that by working, learning, and actively involving local hosts, who possess valuable insights into the land, climate, and soils, we can co-create resilient communities and sustain regenerative practices.

Collaborating with host communities provides us with additional access to land and a wealth of local knowledge. This synergy not only enhances our collective understanding but also strengthens the bonds between diverse groups, fostering a sense of belonging and shared responsibility.

Through shared experiences, we are nurturing a community that thrives on resilience, sustainability, and unity. Together, we are building a future where collaboration and mutual respect form the foundation for lasting change.

Join us in celebrating the power of collaboration and the beauty of diverse perspectives as we pave the way for a regenerative and harmonious community.

text:
üåç‚ú® Celebrating World Refugee Day: "Hope Away from Home" ‚ú®üåç

As we commemorate World Refugee Day under the inspiring theme of "Hope Away from Home," Unidos is thrilled to announce an incredible event hosted by the Department of Women's Empowerment: the 2nd Edition of "What is your entrepreneurial story?"

We are honored to have esteemed speakers join us for this occasion. A special welcome to the amazing Amina Mohamed, CEO of Cameras for Girls, and Olga Kahindo, Founder of Wise Women for Development Association. Their entrepreneurial journeys are sure to captivate and inspire us all.

We eagerly anticipate the unveiling of their stories, knowing that through their remarkable successes, countless women will be empowered, inspired, and motivated to co-create positive change within their communities away from home.

Join us in celebrating the resilient spirit of refugees and the transformative power of entrepreneurship on this World Refugee Day.

text:
On this momentous occasion of World Refugee Day, we reflect on the remarkable journey we have embarked upon together, creating a home away from home and positively impacting the lives of thousands of refugees in Nakivale. 

Our hearts overflow with gratitude towards the global community and our exceptional partners, whose unwavering support and generous donations have made all of this possible.

Together, we have transformed adversity into hope, and through our collective efforts, we continue to build a brighter future for every individual in our resilient community.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Join Us in Supporting UNIDOS - Empowering Refugees through Regenerative Agriculture and Permacultureü§ù

Dear Friends,

I hope this message finds you well. I wanted to share some important information with you regarding a community called UNIDOS, dedicated to teaching regenerative agriculture and permaculture to the residents of the Nakivale refugee settlement in Uganda.

Initially reliant on food aid from different humanitarian Organisations, UNIDOS has taken significant strides towards independence. However, with support dwindling to just 13000 UGX, equivalent to a mere $3.48 per month, it has become increasingly challenging for the approximately 150,000 people in the settlement to sustain themselves.

Over the past few years, UNIDOS has made remarkable progress in organizing and educating refugees on growing their own food using permaculture principles. This approach fosters independence and empowers individuals through sustainable practices. Additionally, the organization has been conducting soap-making classes, particularly benefiting women, to help them establish their own businesses.

To further advance our mission, UNIDOS is planning a fundraising event in the near future and hopes to garner support through organic growth. The team is currently seeking influencers with the right credentials who could help amplify our message and increase their online visibility. While there is no financial compensation involved, we would greatly appreciate your voluntary assistance in spreading the word about their cause.

Before committing, I encourage you to explore our website at

for more detailed information. Your support in promoting our work would be invaluable.

Together, we can accomplish so much more. If you'd like to reach out to UNIDOS directly, you can find our contact details on their website, or feel free to reply to this message.

Thank you for your consideration. We look forward to hearing from you and joining forces to support this meaningful cause.

Warm regards,
Paulinho Muzaliwa

text:
üå±üåç Join us at Unidos, where we believe in transforming lives through education and empowering communities. Our commitment goes beyond just the outcomes of our education methodology; we strive to witness lasting change in the lives of our participants.

Curious to hear what people have to say after experiencing our transformative Permaculture course? üåøüåæ Watch these incredible participants share their stories and experiences. Witness the profound impact our Permaculture program has had on their farming approach and their lives.

At Unidos, we're excited to see how these newfound skills will empower them to improve their farming techniques and create sustainable livelihoods. Stay tuned as we celebrate their journeys of growth and resilience.

Join us in supporting and uplifting one another on this remarkable journey towards self-sufficiency and a brighter future. Together, we can make a difference.

Join us in our upcoming Fundraising campaign in supporting more farmers across Nakivale as we empower them to cultivate healthier crops and, together, build a more sustainable future. Let's make a difference and promote food security for all. ü§ùüåç

It is obvious that people are throwing away at least 30% of their food.

We also take this opportunity to recycle this food waste and, decompose them into our vermicompost, and in return we get an organic fertilizer able to regenerate our soil and enable higher yield productivity.

Join us in regenerating together Nakivale refugee settlement and enable us to promote food security in a refugee settlement

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
An exciting and incredible journey awaits us as we work hand in hand with the inspiring Juru community in our Permaculture Design course focused on Soil Regeneration.

Learning together has been nothing short of magical, witnessing the immense talent and determination that these individuals possess. Their courage and unwavering motivation have ignited a spark within us to continue educating and showcasing the potential of a regenerative community, even in the midst of a seemingly hopeless place like a refugee settlement.

We invite you to be a part of our vision, supporting us on this transformative path. Together, we aim to turn refugee settlements into regenerative and resilient communities, where abundant food, clean water, and quality education become accessible to all.

Let's create a brighter future and empower these communities to thrive. Join us in this journey of hope and possibility.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Our impact on the land, air, water, and people around us is undeniable. Every action we take ripples through our environment, leaving a lasting trace. üåç But here's the powerful truth: Sustainable choices pave the way for positive change and resilience. Unlike unsustainable actions that leave destruction in their wake, embracing sustainability empowers us to nurture a better world for our generation and beyond.

With immense pride, we extend a warm welcome to our 8th cohort of the Permaculture Design Course here at Unidos. üå± 
This Monday, we were deeply moved by the boundless inspiration, incredible talents, and creative ideas that our participants brought to the table. Together, we delved into the heart of sustainability and unsustainability in a changing world.

As we embark on this transformative journey, we're thrilled to witness the remarkable potential within each of these individuals.
 Our training is not just a one-way street. We're here to share our knowledge of permaculture, but equally eager to learn from their unique experiences and stories.

Join us in celebrating the power of sustainable living and the beautiful connections we're forging. Here's to a future where our actions leave a legacy of growth, abundance, and harmony.

As we embark on this transformative journey, we're thrilled to witness the remarkable potential within each of these individuals.
 Our training is not just a one-way street. We're here to share our knowledge of permaculture, but equally eager to learn from their unique experiences and stories.

Join us in celebrating the power of sustainable living and the beautiful connections we're forging. Here's to a future where our actions leave a legacy of growth, abundance, and harmony.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Did you know that enrolling in a Permaculture Design course is far more than just learning? üå±

In Nakivale refugee settlement, where over 15,000 families find their haven, hailing from diverse corners like DR Congo, Burundi, Rwanda, Somalia, South Sudan, Ethiopia, and Eritrea, this course transcends traditional education. At Unidos, our mission is to forge connections that go beyond the classroom, fostering a profound sense of belonging. Through shared stories and the exchange of experiences, we weave a tapestry of unity among these vibrant backgrounds.

What's truly exhilarating is our unique approach in infusing joy into every aspect of the course, enabling participants to tangibly grasp the essence of "People Care." üåç The journey isn't just enlightening; it's enjoyable, as we immerse ourselves in the authentic spirit of empathy and mutual support.

And that's not all. This voyage propels us into a realm of community inclusion, where every voice matters. It's about crafting solutions that resonate, that sustain, and that respond to the very pulse of our community's needs. üí¨

Join us in this dynamic tapestry of learning, sharing, and growing together. Let's nurture not only bountiful gardens but also lasting bonds, as we embrace the true essence of "People Care" and forge a future that thrives on unity and collective empowerment.

text:
Dear Friends
Today we are excited to announce our Fundraising Campaign run by my friend  Mariana on behalf of

,

The undeniable truth is that climate change is transforming our beloved Earth into an inhospitable place, indifferent to our whereabouts or identities. üåç

Regrettably, those most affected by this global crisis are the individuals surviving on a meager $3 per month. This harsh reality is the daily life for those residing in Nakivale refugee settlement, Uganda.

Yet, within this adversity, a spark of resilience ignites. Amidst the struggle, we stand united with the most creative and innovative minds, determined to rewrite the narrative of pain into triumphant tales of success.

Now is the moment for us to cast aside the shadows of inequality and ego. Let's redefine our values, ones rooted in regeneration, that empower each and every soul, transcending geographical boundaries. Together, we can harvest a world abundant with sustenance, access to pure air and clean water, and a collective determination to combat the climate crisis.

Embark on this journey with us, as we launch a fundraising campaign with the potential to transform the lives of 1500 refugees by donating here

and  share it widely to your amazing network that believes in our cause. 

Together, we aim to restore their ability to cultivate enough food to eat twice a day, providing them with agricultural tools, seeds, and most importantly, hope within the refugee settlement.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Addressing Climate Change in Nakivale Refugee Settlement

The impact of climate change is becoming increasingly complex worldwide, and nowhere is this challenge more evident than in refugee settlements, where livelihoods often hinge on agriculture.

In Nakivale refugee settlement, located in Uganda, farmers are facing an uphill battle as they eagerly await the arrival of rain. The dry season has now extended for eight long months, and there is no certainty when the rain will finally arrive.

The prolonged dry season is a pressing issue as time waits for no one. With each passing day, the situation becomes more critical, and the rain remains elusive. If this pattern continues, the price of food in the market is expected to skyrocket, potentially tripling the current rates.

We extend an earnest invitation to everyone reading this to join us in making a difference. 
You can contribute to our campaign

or volunteer with us to prevent this impending crisis. 

Our mission is to educate and demonstrate to farmers the principles of holistic land management, water storage, drainage systems, swales, and other innovative designs. These practices will empower farmers to grow food even in the face of a prolonged dry season.

By coming together and taking action, we can equip these farmers with the knowledge and tools they need to adapt to the changing climate and ensure food security for themselves and their communities.

 Join us in making a positive impact on the lives of those affected by climate change in Nakivale refugee settlement. Together, we can create a more resilient and sustainable future.

messages.text:
We are thrilled to celebrate the graduation of our 8th cohort from the Permaculture Design  Course (PDC) here in Nakivale. Learning and accomplishing this course together has been a source of immense pride for us.

We firmly believe that this achievement marks the beginning of a significant milestone in our ongoing efforts to combat hunger crises in Nakivale. 

Our focus on spreading regenerative approaches, particularly in soil regeneration and climate adaptation for annual crops, aims to ensure consistent productivity in both seasons.

Together, let's embark on a journey to co-create a new civilization where regenerative agriculture serves as the bedrock for improving livelihoods in refugee settlements. 

This course has equipped us with valuable skills and knowledge, and we are committed to applying them to make a positive impact on our community.

text:
To transition to regenerative food production, prioritizing soil health is paramount.

At Unidos, we don't just focus on improving soil health; we are actively regenerating the land through vermicomposting ü™±.

Today, we are thrilled to announce the successful completion and operation of our second vermicompost unit, situated in our demonstration site at Kabazana. We eagerly anticipate optimizing vermicompost production and utilization within our community.

This approach not only benefits the environment but also strengthens our resilience to climate change while sequestering carbon in the soil.

 Our ultimate goal is to foster a regenerative and self-reliant farming community that not only thrives but also nurtures Mother Earth. üå±

text:
Refugee farmers in Nakivale face increasing vulnerability to climate change due to traditional practices and the use of chemical fertilizers. The past farming cycle was particularly challenging, marked by an extended drought that left many without seeds for the upcoming season.

We are pleased to have distributed seeds to nearly 70 farmers for the upcoming farming cycle. 
Our mission is to ensure they do not face the same challenges again.

 Join us in supporting Nakivale's farmers by contributing any amount you can spare, as it can make a difference in the life of at least one farmer here
Together, we can empower and uplift our community. üåæü§ù

text:
üå± Join Our Basecamp on Soil Regeneration! üå±

Are you a Permaculture enthusiast, a farmer, an educator, or a business owner in the vicinity of Nakivale Refugee Settlement? Do you believe in the power of healthy soil for bountiful, nutrient-rich food production? If so, we have an exciting opportunity just for you!

What's Happening?
Unidos Social Innovation Center invites you to our Basecamp event on Monday, 20th November. It's a unique opportunity to dive deep into the world of holistic soil management and various approaches to not only regenerate your soil but also transform it into a source of health, productivity, and delicious homegrown food and beverages. ü•¨

Why Attend?
Healthy soil is the foundation of sustainable and abundant food production. By participating in this event, you'll gain valuable insights into regenerative agriculture, sustainable practices, and the secrets to nurturing your soil for healthier, more productive gardens.

Event Details:

Date: Monday, 20th November
Time: 9AM- 5PM 
Location: Unidos Social Innovation Center (Kashojwa B)

Registration Deadline: Thursday, 17th November
How to Register:
To secure your spot, follow these simple steps:

Contact Us:

Reach out to Unidos Social Innovation Center for more information and registration details.
 You can  contact us here +256 740 107483 

Once you've connected with us, we'll provide you with the registration link, or instructions to complete your registration.
Mark Your Calendar:

Don't forget to mark Monday, 20th November, on your calendar. We can't wait to see you there!

 Come ready to learn and share Remember, the deadline for registration is 17th November, so secure your spot today!

Unidos Social Innovation Center is dedicated to fostering sustainable agriculture and nurturing a community of like-minded individuals who believe in the power of healthy soil. Together, we can create a greener, more abundant future. üåèüåæ

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
messages.text:
We are honored to organize the amazing Basecamp, an event that has been so inspiring, engaging, and a learning experience for all of us in the Refugees community. We gathered to discuss the crucial topic of healthy soil for greater organic food production. 

We have also been deeply inspired by the different initiatives that our community came up with to regenerate the soil. 

We strongly believe that by putting together our wisdom and great ideas and working with nature rather than competing with it, we can produce enough nutritious food for our families while responding to climate change.

text:
üåøüåæ Witness the incredible impact of permaculture in action!

 Meet Sadiki Michael, an inspiring individual who, along with his colleagues, embarked on an enriching journey in permaculture through our program.

Their dedication led them to join Agro-room, a thriving venture specializing in mushroom cultivation in Nakivale. We couldn't be more amazed by their recent achievements!

As we kickstart this new year, our Unidos team had the privilege of visiting their garden farm. What we saw was truly remarkable‚Äîa vibrant space designed by Sadiki and his team, yielding an abundant variety of vegetables including carrotsü•ï , Onions üßÖ , and Irish potatoes ü•î .

The beauty lies in their use of permaculture principles, demonstrating how one can grow a diversity of nutritious food even within limited space. It's a testament to innovation and sustainability!

At Unidos, we take immense pride in supporting visionaries like Sadiki in Nakivale. We invite you to join hands with us‚Äîwhether through donations or volunteering‚Äîto be a part of this transformative journey. Together, let's continue changing lives in the Nakivale refugee settlement.

üåü Join us in making a difference! üåü

text_entities.text:
üåøüåæ Witness the incredible impact of permaculture in action!

 Meet Sadiki Michael, an inspiring individual who, along with his colleagues, embarked on an enriching journey in permaculture through our program.

Their dedication led them to join Agro-room, a thriving venture specializing in mushroom cultivation in Nakivale. We couldn't be more amazed by their recent achievements!

As we kickstart this new year, our Unidos team had the privilege of visiting their garden farm. What we saw was truly remarkable‚Äîa vibrant space designed by Sadiki and his team, yielding an abundant variety of vegetables including carrotsü•ï , Onions üßÖ , and Irish potatoes ü•î .

The beauty lies in their use of permaculture principles, demonstrating how one can grow a diversity of nutritious food even within limited space. It's a testament to innovation and sustainability!

At Unidos, we take immense pride in supporting visionaries like Sadiki in Nakivale. We invite you to join hands with us‚Äîwhether through donations or volunteering‚Äîto be a part of this transformative journey. Together, let's continue changing lives in the Nakivale refugee settlement.

üåü Join us in making a difference! üåü

text:
üå± Did you know that simply adding fertilizer to the soil isn't enough for true soil health? 
Soil regeneration requires a holistic approach to maximize micro-organisms and enhance productivity. One effective method is planting nitrogen-fixing crops and trees, enriching the soil ecosystem and reducing the need for synthetic nitrogen fertilizers in agriculture.

üå≥ Exciting Update! Over the past three months, we've taken a significant step towards soil regeneration by growing peanuts (gnut) in a challenging, poor soil at our demonstration site. Today, we're thrilled to announce a harvest of almost 100kg from a compact 20 square meters! This space served as our testing ground for the organic fertilizer produced by our vermicompost unit.

üåø Witnessing the positive impact on both crops and soil health has been incredibly rewarding. It's a testament to the power of sustainable, regenerative practices. We couldn't be happier about the progress we're making and the potential for transforming agriculture sustainably.

üåç Here's to more strides in regenerating our soil and creating a healthier, more sustainable future!
üåæ‚ú®

text:
üå± Exciting News! üå±
 We're thrilled to announce the successful harvest of our first batch of mushrooms! A big shoutout to the incredible Minak team for their seamless project implementation and heartfelt gratitude to Realiance for their unwavering support in making this dream a reality.

üçÑ What's even more thrilling? 

We've not only harvested but also dived into the world of culinary exploration, testing the possibilities for value addition. 
Our goal is to empower 150 women with the skills to grow mushrooms - a regenerative, nutritious, and easily cultivated food source. 

We firmly believe that by cultivating mushrooms, these women will not only generate income but also provide their families with a healthy, low-cost food option, aiming to decrease malnutrition rates, especially among children in the refugee settlement.

üöÄ Now, our sights are set on scaling up our mushroom production to meet market demands. The journey ahead is promising, and we can't wait to witness the positive impact it will have on the lives of women in the refugee community. Your continued support means the world to us, and we're grateful for each step forward on this empowering path.
üåç‚ú®

text:
üåø Exciting Progress Update in Kyangwale Refugee Settlement and Kyeya Village! üåç

What a great start to the week! We are incredibly proud to share the progress witnessed by our team in Kyangwale refugee settlement and Kyeya village. 

The incredible work from the people we trained last November in permaculture, particularly in designing micro food forests, has been truly remarkable.

The concept of the Food Forest fits seamlessly into these areas heavily impacted by climate change, where access to even a single meal is a significant challenge.

 In collaborationü§ù with

, our Food Forest has been designed to empower the community, mitigating the impact of climate-related challenges on food production. 

‚û°Ô∏èThis initiative aims to reduce dependence on external food aid while enhancing food security by promoting biodiversity and improving soil health.

We're excited about the positive outcomes and the community's commitment to implementing what they've learned.

 Together, we are fostering a future where everyone can afford not just a meal, but a diverse range of nutritious, organic ,locally grown produce.

Stay tuned for more updates on our journey towards a greener, more resilient future! üå≥üíö

text:
üéâ‚ú® Exciting News! üåç‚ú®

I am beyond thrilled to share with you that I have been honored with the Gene Dewey Refugee Award by USA for UNHCR! üèÜ‚ú®

This incredible recognition is not just about me; it's a testament to the collective efforts in advocating for and empowering refugees in Uganda.

The award, named after the remarkable Arthur "Gene" Dewey, symbolizes a commitment to serving and protecting refugees, a cause that resonates deeply with my mission.

To mark this achievement, the announcement will coincide with UNHCR's 2024 regional refugee response plan in Uganda. I'm excited to amplify the important work we're doing and shed light on the challenges and triumphs faced by refugees.

A special shoutout to Suzanne and the USA for UNHCR team for their support.
Thank you all for being part of this incredible journey. Together, we can make a difference. üåüüåà

Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Today has been a fulfilling day dedicated to the incredible journey of harvesting our vermicompost ‚Äì a remarkable organic fertilizer produced from nearly 2 tonnes of food waste. 

Our aim is to harness the power of nature in the form of worm castings to contribute to the development of regenerative Food Forests at Nakivale Refugee Settlement üå≥üå≤ .

ü™± Wondering why we chose Vermicompost? 

1Ô∏è‚É£It's not just about recycling food waste; it's a catalyst for soil regeneration. Packed with essential nutrients like nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), and micronutrients such as calcium and magnesium, this magical compost enhances crop resilience against drought and improves water retention in the soil.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Beyond that, the benefits extend to the environment. By fostering nitrogen-fixing microbes, we're maximizing food production in a way that actively repairs and restores our surroundings.

Excited to witness the positive impact of our efforts in creating a sustainable and thriving ecosystem. 
Join us on this green journey! üåø
üåç

text:
üåç Happy International Women's Day! üå∏

In the spirit of resilience and strength, today we celebrate the remarkable women in refugee communities around the world. The theme for this year, "Inspire Inclusion," holds profound significance as we acknowledge the unique challenges faced by refugee women and their incredible contributions to society.

Refugee women are not just survivors; they are architects of change, embodying courage, determination, and hope. Let's take a moment to honor their journeys, stories, and the rich tapestry of experiences they bring to our global community.

Inclusion for refugee women means recognizing their skills, amplifying their voices, and creating spaces where they can thrive. Each woman brings a unique perspective that enriches our collective narrative, reminding us that true strength lies in diversity.

This International Women's Day, let's stand in solidarity with refugee women, uplift their narratives, and work together to build a world where every woman, regardless of her background, finds a place of belonging and opportunity.

Share your stories, support organizations working towards refugee empowerment, and let's inspire inclusion in every corner of the world. üíôüå∏

text:
üßë‚ÄçüåæWomen leading the way in Climate Resilience üåøüå¥üå≥üåæ

Did you know that women are often at the forefront of climate resilience efforts, especially in refugee settlements? 

Their resilience and resourcefulness are invaluable in adapting to and mitigating the effects of climate change.

In many refugee communities like Kyangwale and Nakivale, women play a central role in securing food, water, and shelter, despite facing immense challenges. 

From regenerative farming techniques to community-led initiatives for abundant organic food , women are driving change and building resilience against environmental challenges.

Let's celebrate the strength and determination of women in refugee settlements who are leading the way in climate resilience. Together, we can support and amplify their voices, ensuring that their knowledge and experiences are recognized and integrated into broader climate adaptation strategies.

üí¨ Share your thoughts: How can we further empower and support women in refugee settlements to enhance climate resilience? Let's spark meaningful conversations and take action for a more sustainable future!

text:
üì¢ Exciting News Alert! 

We are thrilled to announce that Unidos Social Innovation Center‚Äôs 'Regenerate the Soil (REGESOIL)' project has been selected as one of the four winners of the prestigious 2024 Ockenden International Prize! üéâüåç

This incredible recognition comes from a panel of eight esteemed judges who lauded REGESOIL as a vital agricultural initiative, organized by refugees for refugees.

 Through providing ecological farming instruction, training, and support for permaculture, REGESOIL is empowering communities, improving soil productivity, and providing life-saving nutrition for families in need. üå±üí™

What's even more astounding is that out of 56 countries represented in this year's record-breaking 174 submissions, our project emerged victorious as one of the four winners! üåéüèÜ

 To our incredible supporters, partners, and the entire Unidos community, none of this would be possible without your unwavering dedication and belief in our mission. Thank you for being a part of this journey with us! 
You can learn more here about the Prizes
Let's continue to make positive change together! üåü

text:
Did you know that vermicomposting is one of the safest and most eco-friendly methods for managing organic waste? This bioremediation process, facilitated by earthworms, converts organic waste into nutrient-rich compost sustainably.

Earthworms aren't just soil dwellers; they're vital waste decomposers, playing crucial roles in maintaining ecological balance. When we engage communities in food waste recycling, we not only mitigate environmental degradation risks but also create part-time job opportunities, especially for young people in refugee settlements where unemployment rates are as high as 40%.

Moreover, through vermicomposting, we produce organic fertilizer rich in nutrients. This benefits farmers by reducing the need for agro-chemical inputs and helps regenerate soil, making it more productive in the long run.

Let's embrace sustainable practices like vermicomposting to nurture our environment, create economic opportunities, and support agriculture for a healthier, greener future! üå±

text:
üåü Meet the Minds Behind Unidos Social Innovation üåü

At Unidos Social Innovation, we believe in the power of horizontal leadership‚Äîa collaborative, decentralized approach that prioritizes shared decision-making, cooperation, and inclusivity within our Refugee-led organization and community.

Our Unstoppable team comprises experienced, self-driven individuals with a remarkable diversity of passions. From regenerative agriculture to holistic land management, climate activism, and Permaculture expertise, each member brings unique insights to the table. Together, we not only understand the challenges but also possess the ability to co-create impactful solutions for communities.

Join us in our journey towards innovation, collaboration, and positive change!

text:
üåü Celebrating Remarkable Progress: Meet the Amazing Furaha Bahati and the Eagles Power Group! üåü

We're thrilled to share the incredible journey of Furaha Bahati, a single mother residing in Nakivale Refugee Settlement. She's part of the Eagles Power Group, a team of 15 remarkable women who embarked on a transformative journey into cultivating Oyster mushroomsüçÑ.

Since their intensive Mushroom training session on March 15th, these women have not only mastered the art of mushroom farming but have also become an inspiration to their community.

Their dedication to sustainable agriculture and food security has yielded bountiful harvests, not only for sustenance but also for generating vital income. The vibrant images of their flourishing mushroom crops speak volumes about their hard work and the effectiveness of the training they received. These pictures aren't just snapshots; they narrate tales of empowerment, resilience, and the triumph of collective effort.

The success of Furaha and the Eagles Power Group is a direct reflection of your generous support. Your contributions haven't just provided resources for mushroom cultivation; they've planted seeds of hope and economic independence for these women. As they share their harvest with others, they spread the message that with the right support and determination, growth is possible in every sense.

Our deepest gratitude goes out to you all  for your unwavering support and belief in our mission. Together, we're not just growing mushrooms; we're nurturing a brighter future for Women and Children in Nakivale Refugee Settlement.
