Since their intensive Mushroom training session on March 15th, these women have not only mastered the art of mushroom farming but have also become an inspiration to their community.

Their dedication to sustainable agriculture and food security has yielded bountiful harvests, not only for sustenance but also for generating vital income. The vibrant images of their flourishing mushroom crops speak volumes about their hard work and the effectiveness of the training they received. These pictures aren't just snapshots; they narrate tales of empowerment, resilience, and the triumph of collective effort.

The success of Furaha and the Eagles Power Group is a direct reflection of your generous support. Your contributions haven't just provided resources for mushroom cultivation; they've planted seeds of hope and economic independence for these women. As they share their harvest with others, they spread the message that with the right support and determination, growth is possible in every sense.

Our deepest gratitude goes out to you all  for your unwavering support and belief in our mission. Together, we're not just growing mushrooms; we're nurturing a brighter future for Women and Children in Nakivale Refugee Settlement.

text:
üå≥üåø Designing Our Food Forest: Beyond Planting Trees and Crops üåøüå≥

When creating our food forest, it's not just about planting trees and crops. We consider several vital points that shape its success:

1. Efficient Use of Space: Our food forest is a multi-layered ecosystem, mirroring natural forests. Every inch is carefully planned to maximize productivity and biodiversity.

2. Ecosystem Resilience: Thoughtful design enhances resilience by promoting biodiversity and providing habitat for beneficial organisms, reducing vulnerability to pests and diseases.

3. Sustainable Resource Management: We incorporate water catchment, soil conservation, and nutrient cycling into our design, minimizing reliance on external inputs and reducing environmental impact.

4. Accessibility and Maintenance: Our food forest is designed for ease of access and maintenance. Proper layout and spacing make it simple to navigate and care for, ensuring longevity and productivity.

5. Community Inclusion: We involve our community every step of the way, from design to implementation and decision-making. Together, we co-create a space that serves as a hub for engagement and education.

Join us in nurturing our food forest and cultivating a sustainable future for all!

text:
Curious to learn about the holistic activities that make our mission at UNIDOS unique and impactful? üåü

At UNIDOS, we create a space where women are empowered to express themselves, learn, and inspire change. By providing skills and experiences, we help individuals become resilient leaders and changemakers. Through digital education, you can unleash your full potential and open doors to new opportunities.

We focus on regenerative agriculture to improve livelihoods and restore biodiversity. Our soil regeneration and climate activism initiatives promote sustainable practices. Additionally, we transform food waste into organic fertilizer, enhancing food production and supporting our community.

Our comprehensive approach is making a global impact, earning us recognition and awards worldwide. üåç

Join us on this transformative journey! Follow us on social media and visit our website to learn more

text:
üåøüå± Exciting News from Nakivale! üå±üåø

We are thrilled to announce that we have recently produced a fresh batch of nutrient-rich organic fertilizer using our innovative vermicomposting process! ü™±‚ú® This eco-friendly compost is made from recycled food waste, turning an environmental problem into a powerful solution for sustainable agriculture.

üöú In the upcoming farming cycle, we will be distributing this high-quality fertilizer to our dedicated farmers. By applying it to their gardens, we aim to boost food production while nurturing the soil. üåæüåç

Why Our Organic Fertilizer Matters:
Enhanced Crop Yields: Packed with essential nutrients, our organic fertilizer promotes robust plant growth, leading to higher and healthier yields. üçÖü•ï
Soil Health: Unlike chemical fertilizers, our compost enriches the soil structure, improving water retention and reducing erosion. üåßÔ∏èüíß
Sustainable Farming: By returning organic matter to the soil, we create a self-sustaining cycle that supports long-term agricultural productivity. üå±üîÑ
Climate Resilience: Healthier soils are more resilient to climate change impacts like drought, ensuring more stable food production even in challenging conditions. ‚òÄÔ∏èüåßÔ∏è
Together, we are building a regenerative community that values the earth and empowers our farmers. Let‚Äôs cultivate a brighter, greener future! üåøüíö

text:
üåø Empowering Change Through Permaculture! üåø

Meet Yannick Buffole, the Founder of Masoka Nutrition for Development and one of our inspiring Permaculture trainees at Unidos Social Innovation Center. Yannick has transformed a 1-acre plot into a thriving farm in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement. By diversifying crops like onionsüßÖ, beansü´ò, and green peppersü´ë, he has achieved financial independence while helping to combat hunger and malnutrition in a community where many families struggle to afford even one meal a day due to the ongoing humanitarian crisis.

This is the power of sustainable agriculture creating resilience, ensuring food security, and fostering hope for a better future. üíöüå±

Join us in supporting this vital work! Whether through partnership, volunteering, or donations, your contribution can help more refugees become self-sufficient, improve nutrition, and build stronger, more sustainable communities. Together, we can make a difference!

You can also reach out to Yannick directly for more information about his amazing initiative.

text:
Progress Update: Empowering Refugee Farmers with Mushroom Cultivation üçÑ

We are excited to share the progress of our collaboration with Re-alliance and Mycorama in supporting the Minaki Mushroom Project in Nakivale Refugee Settlement. Together, we have developed an illustrated guide üìñ designed to help refugee farmers cultivate mushrooms, offering a sustainable solution to tackle malnutrition üçΩÔ∏è and food insecurity üåæ. This initiative not only addresses critical nutritional needs but also enables farmers to generate income üí∞, improving livelihoods and resilience üí™ in the face of displacement.

Why Mushroom Cultivation?

Nutritional Benefits: üçÑ Mushrooms are rich in essential vitamins and minerals, providing a key source of nutrition for communities facing food insecurity.
Income Generation: üíµ By empowering refugee farmers to grow and sell mushrooms, we are creating economic opportunities that can help reduce poverty and increase financial stability.
Sustainable Agriculture: üåç Mushroom cultivation can be done using locally available materials, making it a low-cost and environmentally friendly farming method that promotes self-reliance.
üì¢ Call to Action
We invite you to explore the illustrated guide and learn how mushroom farming can transform refugee communities. Whether you're a farmer, humanitarian worker, or simply interested in sustainable solutions, this guide is a valuable resource for all.

‚¨áÔ∏è Download the Guide Here:
Join us in empowering communities through innovative agriculture üöú, and be a part of this impactful journey!

In Nakivale Refugee Settlement, a place where more than 200000 families are hosted by the Uganda Government, 85% rely on agriculture for livelihoods, but still climate change makes all farmers' efforts in vain 

The good news is that we‚Äôre advancing

justice by teaching refugees how to co-create food forests that heal the earth and uplift communities. üå≥‚ú® These forests transform degraded land into thriving ecosystems, mitigate climate change, and provide sustainable food sources.

This isn‚Äôt just about planting trees ‚Äî it‚Äôs about addressing inequality by equipping refugees with the skills and tools to restore the land they live on while building climate resilience for future generations. Together, we‚Äôre turning environmental challenges into opportunities for justice and hope. üåæüíö

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Women in Nakivale Refugee Settlement are taking the lead in educating their communities about family planning and reproductive health. üåçüíô Through comprehensive training, they gain the knowledge and confidence to become peer educators, ensuring that accurate information reaches as many people as possible. By organizing group discussions and one-on-one counseling sessions, they break down myths, reduce stigma, and encourage informed decision-making. üó£Ô∏èüìö

A key part of this training is teaching safe contraceptive methods, including proper condom use, to prevent unplanned pregnancies and the spread of STIs. üè•üõ°Ô∏è These women engage men, youth, and couples, fostering a culture where reproductive health is a shared responsibility. They also work closely with health centers to connect families with the services they need.

With access to the right knowledge and resources, we can build a healthier, more resilient community. As long as we are empowering women as educators, we are not only improving family planning awareness but also strengthening the overall well-being of refugee families. üë©üèæ‚Äçü§ù‚Äçüë©üèΩüë®üèø‚Äçü§ù‚Äçüë®üèæ

text:
üì¢ Tackling Malnutrition & Food Insecurity in Nakivale üçÑüå±

With the rising influx of refugees especially from the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Nakivale Refugee Settlement a home to 200.000 Refugees, faces severe food shortages and increasing malnutrition. Thousands of refugees arrive in Nakivale, Uganda, seeking safety and a chance to rebuild their lives.

At UNIDOS, we are working with four groups of refugee women to create the first Mushroom Spawn Multiplication Hub to co-create sustainable solutions for food security and economic empowerment.

üå± Mushroom cultivation, a smart climate solution, is highly nutritious, protein-rich, space-efficient, short, and easy to grow in an environmentally repairing way with local and cost-effective resources, in return It fights malnutrition while also generating income for refugee families.

üí° Through regenerative farming training, food waste recycling, and skill-building, we are empowering refugees to grow and sustain their own food.

‚è≥ The time to act is now! As the refugee population grows, so does the urgency for sustainable solutions.

üåçüíö You Can Help! Donate today to provide training, tools, and resources for mushroom farming in Nakivale. Every contribution helps refugees build a food-secure future!

text:
Celebrating the Strength and Resilience of Women in Nakivale! ‚ú®

On this special occasion of International Women‚Äôs Day, we were honored to be represented alongside key partners and stakeholders, including the Office of the Prime Minister (OPM), UNHCR, district representatives, and NGOs like Alight. Together, we celebrated the resilience, strength, and creativity of refugee women who continue to overcome adversity, gender inequality, and sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) not only in Nakivale Refugee Settlement but across the world.

Women in Nakivale are not just survivors; they are leaders, changemakers, and entrepreneurs, driving economic growth and creating sustainable solutions for their communities. One of the highlights of the day was an exhibition of innovative organic products, showcasing how women are leading the way toward self-reliance and sustainability.

üåø Our Organic Product Exhibition Featured:
‚úÖ Vermicompost ‚Äì Eco-friendly organic fertilizer supporting regenerative agriculture
‚úÖ Moringa-based Organic Soap ‚Äì Natural skincare with healing properties
‚úÖ Shower Jelly ‚Äì A refreshing and locally made hygiene product
‚úÖ Mushrooms ‚Äì A nutritious and income-generating food source

Through these products, women are transforming waste into wealth, building sustainable livelihoods, and proving that they are key players in local economic development. This celebration was a powerful reminder that when women thrive, entire communities prosper.

üôè A huge thank you to everyone who supported us by purchasing our products and encouraging this movement toward economic independence! 

If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, supporting our initiatives, or placing an order, feel free to reach out at

.

üì¢ Let‚Äôs continue to uplift and empower women every day not just on Women‚Äôs Day!

Together, we celebrated the resilience, strength, and creativity of refugee women who continue to overcome adversity, gender inequality, and sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) not only in Nakivale Refugee Settlement but across the world.

Women in Nakivale are not just survivors; they are leaders, changemakers, and entrepreneurs, driving economic growth and creating sustainable solutions for their communities. One of the highlights of the day was an exhibition of innovative organic products, showcasing how women are leading the way toward self-reliance and sustainability.

üåø Our Organic Product Exhibition Featured:
‚úÖ Vermicompost ‚Äì Eco-friendly organic fertilizer supporting regenerative agriculture
‚úÖ Moringa-based Organic Soap ‚Äì Natural skincare with healing properties
‚úÖ Shower Jelly ‚Äì A refreshing and locally made hygiene product
‚úÖ Mushrooms ‚Äì A nutritious and income-generating food source

Through these products, women are transforming waste into wealth, building sustainable livelihoods, and proving that they are key players in local economic development. This celebration was a powerful reminder that when women thrive, entire communities prosper.

üôè A huge thank you to everyone who supported us by purchasing our products and encouraging this movement toward economic independence! 

If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, supporting our initiatives, or placing an order, feel free to reach out at

.

üì¢ Let‚Äôs continue to uplift and empower women every day not just on Women‚Äôs Day!

text:
On this World Refugee Day, we celebrate the power of women and youth leading change in refugee communities!

At Unidos Social Innovation Center, we believe refugees are not defined by their displacement‚Äîbut by their creativity, resilience, and ability to co-create possibilities and solutions that meet human purpose.

From women turning soap-making into livelihoods üßº, to youth transforming food waste into organic fertilizer to heal the soil üå±, and families growing food forests üå≥‚Äîtogether we are shifting from humanitarian dependency towards building a new regenerative, circular economy.

This work not only defines our capacity to innovate and adapt but shows the world that refugees are active contributors to solutions for some of the biggest global crises‚Äîclimate change, food insecurity, and poverty. Even in places often described as hopeless, like refugee camps, regeneration is happening.

Refugees, we are not waiting for help. We are building solutions. We are driving regeneration.

üëâ Join us on this journey!
Whether by sharing our story, partnering with us, donating, or volunteering‚Äîyou can be part of transforming refugee settlements into thriving regenerative communities.

text:
What if refugee settlements could become models of regeneration and resilience?
We‚Äôre not just imagining it, we‚Äôre making it happen.

‚ú® Curious about how we‚Äôre co-creating a new way of living in Nakivale?
Our founder shares how we‚Äôre transforming challenges into opportunities through a regenerative, holistic approach from recycling waste to healing the soil, growing healthy organic food, restoring biodiversity, and building climate resilience.

üçÄ This is to create a new civilization where thousands of refugees will be empowered in the next 3 years to tackle food insecurity and shift from humanitarian aid dependents to become self-reliant to improve their livelihood.

üé• Watch the full video here
and see how a refugee settlement is becoming a beacon of hope for a regenerative future, and if this resonates with your values, you can join us by donating
or sharing our campaign widely.

text:
Did you know that for a community to achieve true food sovereignty, we must start with soil regeneration?

In Nakivale, 85% of families depend on agriculture, yet many still face poor harvests even when using chemicals. The soil is degraded, infertile, and in urgent need of healing.

üí° Curious how we are responding?
Watch our holistic, regenerative solution that transforms waste into value, promotes a circular economy, restores soil health, and empowers farmers to grow abundantly and sustainably. üåç‚ú®

üëâ Watch here:
üåü Join us in co-creating a future where refugee communities thrive in food sovereignty, resilience, and ecological abundance. Together, we can regenerate the soil and restore hope. üíö

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
In refugee settlements like Kyangwali and Nakivale in Uganda, every tree we plant tells a story ,a story of renewal, resilience, and togetherness.

Each seed we put in the ground is a reminder that if we don‚Äôt act now, the effects of climate change will shape our future, but through action, we can reshape it. üåç

Through our Food Forest Initiative, over 1500 refugee and host families are transforming dry, depleted land into vibrant green oases. Together, they‚Äôve planted more than 10,000 trees that now provide fruits, shade, and safe spaces for birds and pollinators. üêùüçå

These trees do more than grow ,they heal.
üåø They restore biodiversity, turning once-barren land into thriving ecosystems.
üåæ They build climate resilience, capturing carbon and reducing the impact of floods and droughts.
üçé They strengthen food security, ensuring families harvest nutritious food right at home.

But most beautifully, they unite people , from different countries, languages, and stories , through one shared purpose: planting trees for a shared and hopeful future. üíö

Everywhere we work, we see proof that when communities take root in the soil, hope grows with them. üå±

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
3.5 billion people still lack safe sanitation ,almost half the world.
On World Toilet Day, we‚Äôre reminded that a toilet is never ‚Äújust‚Äù a toilet.

In Nakivale Refugee Settlement, home to 200,000 people, sanitation coverage is only 36%.
That gap is the difference between illness and health, fear and dignity, stagnation and possibility.

At Unidosprojects  with partner Generation Restoration e.V.   we‚Äôve built 14 composting toilets for 14 families and the impact is already visible.

What one composting toilet unlocks:
‚Ä¢ Hygiene, safety, and privacy
‚Ä¢ Dignity and protection
‚Ä¢ A circular system turning waste into nutrient-rich compost
‚Ä¢ Healthier soils and stronger crops
‚Ä¢ More food security and renewed hope

This is regenerative sanitation ‚Äîand we‚Äôre just getting started.

Our next goal: Build 10 more composting toilets with local leadership and community ownership.

üëâ Support regenerative sanitation where it‚Äôs needed most:

Regeneration begins with dignity.
Dignity begins with a toilet.

messages.from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
Six years ago, we co-created UNIDOS with nothing but a dream‚Äîto build a space of belonging, dignity, and hope for refugees in Nakivale. We had no resources, no funding, and no land‚Ä¶ only courage, passion, and the desire to survive together.

We began with 30 people, meeting under trees, turning food waste into fertilizer, planting seeds in dry soil, training youth, empowering women, and co-creating solutions from what was available. We lived through COVID-19, shrinking humanitarian aid, climate shocks, and deep food insecurity‚Äîbut our community kept rising.

Today, thousands of refugees have been empowered through UNIDOS. We‚Äôve restored land, created jobs, supported farmers, built youth leadership, and cultivated regenerative food systems. What started as survival has become a global example of resilience and community innovation.

As UNIDOS celebrates 6 years, we choose to honor this journey by sharing food with 200 newly arrived refugees‚Äîpeople who are starting from zero, just like we once did.

You can celebrate with us.
$5 feeds one person.
Donate here:
Thank you for standing beside us. Together, we are building the future we once dreamed of
